1.text: Boast not yourself of to morrow; for you know not what a day may bring forth.

2.text: Let another man praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.

4.text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?

5.text: Open rebuke is better than secret love.

6.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

7.text: The full soul loathes an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

8.text: As a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man that wanders from his place.

9.text: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so does the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.

10.text: Your own friend, and your father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into your brother’s house in the day of your calamity: for better is a neighbor that is near than a brother far off.

11.text: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproaches me.

12.text: A prudent man foresees the evil, and hides himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.

13.text: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

14.text: He that blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.

15.text: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

16.text: Whoever hides her hides the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which denudes itself.

17.text: Iron sharpens iron; so a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.

18.text: Whoever keeps the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waits on his master shall be honored.

19.text: As in water face answers to face, so the heart of man to man.

20.text: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

21.text: As the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.

22.text: Though you should bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.

23.text: Be you diligent to know the state of your flocks, and look well to your herds.

24.text: For riches are not for ever: and does the crown endure to every generation?

25.text: The hay appears, and the tender grass shows itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.

26.text: The lambs are for your clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.

27.text: And you shall have goats’ milk enough for your food, for the food of your household, and for the maintenance for your maidens.
